item.dc:creator: @_s11 s1gma
item.description:
@_s11 wrote:

[quote=“Cres, post:29, topic:442469”]After some thinking I decided to change some things…

  1. Will implement MINA networking (rip it from original PI).
  2. Will adjust ticking and player updating (Won’t be updating all the connected players individually with every tick.)
  3. The content framework will still exist; the source will hold content for most revision though only the content supported by the PI client will work.
    General content shall remain the same.
  4. I’ll be using constants so all that is required to change the server to work other clients will be a few* numbers.
    *This may add up to somthing bigger than “a few”[/quote]
    Netty pretty much deprecates MINA

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @Cres Cres
item.description:
@Cres wrote:

After some thinking I decided to change some things…

  1. Will implement MINA networking (rip it from original PI).
  2. Will adjust ticking and player updating (Won’t be updating all the connected players individually with every tick.)
  3. The content framework will still exist; the source will hold content for most revision though only the content supported by the PI client will work.
    General content shall remain the same.
  4. I’ll be using constants so all that is required to change the server to work other clients will be a few* numbers.
    *This may add up to somthing bigger than “a few”

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @_s11 s1gma
item.description:
@_s11 wrote:

[quote=“Cres, post:23, topic:442469”][quote author=_s link=topic=545161.msg3997745#msg3997745 date=1337514615]

Sinisoul (or someone else, correct me if I’m wrong) had the dream of adding scripting support to a server in such a way that all you had to do in order to add new content is to provide the script file and it would be ready.

??? lots of people have had that idea

He’s the only one I know of

Once I get the DOM up, I can start adding main content for skills but that’s for later.
Currently writing the engine and then I’ll do the player’s equipment and inventory (after adding items).

Scripting has been used to implement game logic for a very long time, and many people have applied to RS servers since 2006, starting with RuneScript clones and later to Jython, JRuby, Lua, etc.

I won’t be using scripting languages; I’ll just build general protocols in Java and apply the data for the actions in XML files.

all you had to do in order to add new content is to provide the script file and it would be ready

that sounded an awful lot like using scripts and an embeddable language for content
[/quote]

My bad. >.<
No, it won’t be a scripting language. I don’t know any but I might learn Lua.
I’ll just make a general protocol(s) and I’ll provide XML files to feed it with content.
Or I can just make it read the data from text files with a FileReader, would it have performance differences?[/quote]xml is generally slower to read in than flatfile data but it is a good format for data representation and i would recommend you use it.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @Cres Cres
item.description:
@Cres wrote:

Contains the player’s levels in all statistics as well the experience.
Here it is though;

[code=java]package runescape.players;

public class Statistics {

public static final int ATTACK = 0;
public static final int DEFENCE = 1;
public static final int STRENGTH = 2;
public static final int HITPOINTS = 3;
public static final int RANGED = 4;
public static final int PRAYER = 5;
public static final int MAGIC = 6;
public static final int COOKING = 7;
public static final int WOODCUTTING = 8;
public static final int FLETCHING = 9;
public static final int FISHING = 10;
public static final int FIREMAKING = 11;
public static final int CRAFTING = 12;
public static final int SMITHING = 13;
public static final int MINING = 14;
public static final int HERBLORE = 15;
public static final int AGILITY = 16;
public static final int THIEVING = 17;
public static final int SLAYER = 18;
public static final int FARMING = 19;
public static final int RUNECRAFTING = 20;

private int[] level = new int[20];
private double[] experience = new double[20];

public Statistics(int[] level, double[] exp) {
	this.level = level;
	this.experience = exp;
}

public void damageStat(int stat, int damage) {
	this.level[stat] -= damage;
	if (this.level[stat] < 0) {
		this.level[stat] = 0;
	}
}

public void improveStat(int stat, int bonus, int cap) {
	this.level[stat] += bonus;
	if (this.level[stat] > cap) {
		this.level[stat] = cap;
	}
}

public void neutralizeStats() {
	for (int i = 0; i < 20; i++) {
		if (i != HITPOINTS || i != PRAYER) {
			if (this.level[i] > getLevelByExp(i)) {
				this.level[i]--;
			} else if (this.level[i] < getLevelByExp(i)) {
				this.level[i]++;
			}
		}
	}
}

public int getLevelByExp(int stat) {
	double exp = this.experience[stat];
	if (exp >= 13034431) return 99;
	double e = 0;
	double b = 0;
	for (int i = 1; i < 100; i++) {
		e += i + 300.0 * Math.pow(2, i/7);
		b = e/4;
		if (b >= exp) return i;
	}
	return 0;
}

}
[/code]

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @Cres Cres
item.description:
@Cres wrote:

All I know of packaging is that you can’t use uppercase letters , except for abbreviations.
Also they should be sorted in importance and size and packages that have to do with eachother should be placed under eachother and not next to eachother.
o.o

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @whackatre Whackatre
item.description:
@whackatre wrote:

[quote=“Cres, post:3, topic:442469”][quote author=whackatre link=topic=545161.msg3995843#msg3995843 date=1337255871]
Why not use proper packaging conventions?

I’ll be waiting for pictures.
[/quote]

Which would be?

So… your going to make a framework with networking and packet processing? ~^

I’m sorry I really do approve of what your doing but 99.9999999999% of the community wouldn’t even dare to use.

It’s a content framework. I show how to add content to a server and maybe I’ll make this a real functional server.
I’m not adding networking yet.[/quote]
Your website.
top level domain.domain.projectname

Examples:

package net.projectrainbow.server; //from projectrainbow.net
package org.apache.bcel; //from apache.org

You DID add your package names like the official Java API ones, but those are exceptions.

If I’m wrong, feel free to correct me.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @Cres Cres
item.description:
@Cres wrote:

Lin:

How will you test your content with no networking?

Not.
Jokes, it should work, the only thing that the networking will do is provide variables from the client. (packet handling)
What I’m making is how the server handles everything with those variables.
EDIT: so if I want to test my methods I can simply provide a random value that was supposedly sended by the client.

Read full topic
